sections.title: Qualifying costs for all your projects
sections.description: Complete all fields, using '0' if you have no costs.

fields.label: inset6
fields.infoText: We will only consider costs for R&D activities that qualify for R&D tax relief.

fields.label: Employee costs
fields.errorMessage: Enter a numeric value for each field. Use ‘0’ if no expenditure is applicable.

fields.label: What employee costs qualify for relief?
fields.infoText:
If you have employees working part-time on R&D activities, you should only include a reasonable share of their total employee costs.

You can include your employees' :

-    salary before tax
including cash bonuses and overtime pay 
-    reimbursed employee expenses to do with R&D activities (where employee have paid for their expenses before the company pays them back)
-    Employer's National Insurance contributions
-    Employer's pension contributions

fields.label: Costs for externally provided workers (EPWs)
fields.infoText: Costs for externally provided workers (EPWs)

fields.label: 100% costs for connected EPWs
fields.helpText: EPWs are workers from a staff agency
fields.errorMessage: Enter a numeric value for each field. Use ‘0’ if no expenditure is applicable.

fields.label: 65% costs for unconnected EPWs
fields.errorMessage: Enter a numeric value for each field. Use ‘0’ if no expenditure is applicable.

fields.label: Are my EPWs connected or unconnected?
fields.infoText:
Your company and the EPWs are connected if both are controlled by the
either the same individual or company that has as a majority share in both.

Where connected, you may only claim relief on the lower amount of:
- your costs of paying the EPWs or
- the EPWs costs

Where unconnected, you may claim 65% of the costs of EPWs.

fields.label: Costs for subcontractors
fields.infoText: Costs for subcontractors

fields.label: Costs for connected subcontractors
fields.errorMessage: Enter a numeric value for each field. Use ‘0’ if no expenditure is applicable.

fields.label: 65% costs for unconnected subcontractors
fields.errorMessage: Enter a numeric value for each field. Use ‘0’ if no expenditure is applicable.

fields.label: Are my subcontractors connected or unconnected?
fields.infoText:
Your company and the subcontractor are connected if both are controlled by the
either the same individual or company that has as a majority share in both.

Where connected, you may only claim relief on the lower amount of:
- your costs of paying the subcontractor or
- the subcontractors own costs

Where unconnected, you may claim 65% of the costs of
subcontractors.

fields.label: Software costs
fields.helpText: Include software licence fees bought for R&D and a reasonable share of the costs for software partly used in your R&D activities
fields.errorMessage: Enter a numeric value for each field. Use ‘0’ if no expenditure is applicable.

fields.label: Consumables costs
fields.helpText: Include costs on materials consumed or transformed in the R&D process, for example, water, fuel, power and laboratory consumables used in trials
fields.errorMessage: Enter a numeric value for each field. Use ‘0’ if no expenditure is applicable.

fields.label: Costs for clinical trial volunteers
fields.helpText:
For R&D projects in the pharmaceutical industry,
include payments made to volunteers involved in clinical tests
fields.errorMessage: Enter a numeric value for each field. Use ‘0’ if no expenditure is applicable.

fields.value: ${EmployeeCosts + software + consumables + clinicalTrial + epwCon + subConCon + epwUnCon + subConUncon}

fields.label: What scientific or technical knowledge existed at the start of your project that you planned to improve?
fields.shortName: Scientific or technical knowledge at the start
fields.helpText: Enter up to 600 words including spaces
fields.errorMessage: Summarise the scientific or technical knowledge at the start of the project

fields.infoText: What advance in that knowledge did you aim to achieve?

fields.label: What is an advance in knowledge or capability?
fields.infoText:
An advance in knowledge or capability in science or technology may have physical consequences or may be an increase in overall knowledge, but in either case, a competent professional working in that field would recognise it as a significant improvement.

The improvements may include:
- creating a process, material, device, product or service that increases the knowledge or capability 
- a visible improvement to an existing process, material, device, product or service like cost savings or less waste
- using science or technology to copy the effect of a current process, material, device, product or service in a new or improved way

fields.helpText:
List the goals of your R&D project, and explain the improvements you planned to make.
Enter up to 600 words including spaces
fields.errorMessage: Enter the knowledge you aimed to achieve

fields.infoText: What scientific or technological uncertainties did you face?

fields.label: What types of uncertainties should I outline?
fields.infoText:
Uncertainties may be when you either:

- do not know if it is possible to create or improve the product or process
- know the product or process can be created from your research but it's too costly 

For example, you tried to build a medical diagnostic tool combining non-invasive testing technology, artificial intelligence (AI) and portability, but you're not sure about the method of updating the AI with the latest medical knowledge.

fields.helpText: Describe the obstacles that you found and tried to overcome to achieve the improvements. Enter up to 600 words including spaces
fields.errorMessage: Enter scientific or technological uncertainties faced

fields.label: **How did your project attempt to overcome these uncertainties?**
fields.infoText: How did your project overcome these uncertainties?

Outline the R&D activities you did to try to resolve the uncertainties. For help with the types of activities you should include, see [paragraph 26 to 32 in this guidance (opens in a new window)](https://www.gov.uk/hmrc-internal-manuals/corporate-intangibles-research-and-development-manual/cird81900).

fields.helpText: Enter up to 600 words including spaces
fields.errorMessage: Enter work done to overcome these uncertainties

fields.errorMessage: Enter total qualifying costs for this project

sections.title: Did your company make a trading loss for the period you are claiming for?
sections.description: If your company has incurred a loss, you can either carry the loss forward against trading profits in the future or give the loss up for a cash payment.

fields.errorMessage: Select yes or no if you have claimed a R&D tax credit

sections.title: What is your company's unused trading loss for this period?

fields.label: How do I work out my unused trading loss?
fields.infoText:
The unused trading loss is:

* the company's trading loss (where the company has spent more than it has made in an accounting period)

* less any other Corporation Tax profits of the claim period 

* less any loss relief claimed

fields.label: declabel
fields.infoText: By submitting this form, you declare that the information that you have provided is true and complete.
If you give incomplete or inaccurate information, we may charge a financial penalty or even prosecute you.

We have sent you a confirmation email.

This is your last opportunity to print or save a PDF copy of your submitted form.

In most cases we aim to either pay the tax credit, or contact you about your application within 28 days.

If we do not hold accurate Bacs (Bankers Automated Clearing System) details, your payment will take longer to process.

If we think the cost details may be incorrect, we aim to open an enquiry within 60 days. HMRC will contact you regarding the enquiry.
